name: Relational DB
description: A database based on the relational model, using SQL. (e.g., Postgres, MySQL)

name: Document DB
description: A NoSQL database that stores data in JSON-like documents. (e.g., MongoDB)

name: Key-Value Store
description: A simple NoSQL database that stores data as a collection of key-value pairs. (e.g., DynamoDB, Redis)

name: Wide-Column Store
description: A NoSQL database that stores data in columns rather than rows. (e.g., Cassandra)

name: Graph DB
description: A NoSQL database that uses graph structures with nodes, edges, and properties. (e.g., Neo4j)

name: Vector DB
description: A database optimized for storing and querying vector embeddings for AI/ML. (e.g., Pinecone, Weaviate)

name: Time-Series DB
description: A database optimized for time-stamped or time-series data. (e.g., InfluxDB, Prometheus)

name: Stream Processor
description: A platform for building real-time data pipelines and streaming apps. (e.g., Kafka, Pulsar)

name: Event Bus
description: A simpler message bus for decoupling services in event-driven architectures. (e.g., AWS EventBridge)

name: In-Memory Cache
description: An in-memory data store used to decrease latency for data access. (e.g., Redis, Memcached)

name: Search Engine
description: A database optimized for text-based search and analytics. (e.g., Elasticsearch, Solr)

name: Orchestrator
description: A platform for deploying and managing containerized applications. (e.g., Kubernetes, Nomad)

name: Service Mesh
description: A dedicated infrastructure layer for managing service-to-service communication. (e.g., Istio, Linkerd)

name: API Gateway
description: Manages API traffic, security, and routing. (e.g., Kong, AWS API Gateway)

name: Object Storage
description: Highly scalable storage for unstructured data (blobs, files). (e.g., S3, MinIO)

name: Data Processing Engine
description: A system for large-scale batch or stream data processing. (e.g., Spark, Flink)

name: Enterprise Service Bus
description: A centralized bus for message routing and transformation in SOA. (e.g., MuleSoft)

name: Data Warehouse
description: A columnar database optimized for analytics and BI reporting. (e.g., Snowflake, BigQuery)

name: In-Memory Data Grid
description: A distributed in-memory store for high-speed compute and data. (e.g., Hazelcast)

name: Observability Platform
description: Tools for collecting, storing, and analyzing logs, metrics, and traces. (e.g., Datadog, Prometheus)
